title: Fremantle Biennale celebrates the port's rich history
text:
What: The Fremantle Biennale will present work from more than 40 local and international artists, architects and designers in a celebration of the city's history.

Headlining the event, from November 1-3, in Esplanade Park, is a large-scale light installation, Waterlicht, from Studio Roosegaarde, which was founded by Dutch artist Daan Roosegaarde. The work's cascading waves of blue light, call attention to rising water levels along Fremantle’s shoreline. A podcast provides an accompanying soundscape.

Waterlicht by Studio Roosegaarde draws attention to the rising waters of climate change. Studio Roosegaarde

Throughout the three weeks of the biennale, a major new commission from WA artist Bennett Miller, Behavioural Ecologies (Red), will take place in the form of interventions, installations and live performances across multiple sites. It will occupy and leave a trail from South Beach and its surroundings, passing through the West End and the port, and ending at the North Mole.

An srtist's impression of the South Mole resort installation. Supplied

A resort like no other will be built on South Mole in a major living installation created by The Commonwealth of New Bayswater, led by Perth artist Jessee Lee Johns. This large-scale performative installation operates autonomously and visitors can engage with the day spa for relaxation, visit the tattoo parlour, shop at the souvenir store, undertake a guided visit at the museum, and even spend a night at the hotel.
description: Waves of blue light will arc over the city in an event featuring works from local and international artists, architects and designers.
